title: Can I use a photo of David Hamilton's as the cover art of an album without being sued? - Quora

response.answer_text: The only way you can use a photo of David Hamilton as the cover art of an album without being sued is to get permission from both the photo’s copyright owner as well as from any human subjects in the photograph. This will involve getting a license agreement from the copyright owner and a release form from the photograph’s subject(s), if any.

Well, you’d be pretty obviously taking his copyrighted work and using it without permission so I would say no? Whether you get sued or not depends on whether the rights owner objects, which they will as a matter of course. It might be covered by Fair Use if you were to use the photo in a really transformative way, but that is something that depends on the laws where you are - and whether a court would agree that it’s properly transformative.

No for two reasons. First, you didn't take the photo and you would have to have permission from the photographer. Second, by using the photo, you imply an endorsement by David Hamilton which is false.

Yes, if you purchase the right to use it in that way from whoever currently owns the copyright to that particular photograph. Fail to acquire the legal right to do so, and you’ll be lucky to only owe the copyright holder all of the proceeds from selling your album. 😁

How widely will this cover be distributed?Will people buy your album because his photo is the cover?Who is David Hamilton?If a record company owns Hamilton’s distribution rights, they could sue just for publicity.
Only if you get permission from Hamilton or his representatives. … It’s like asking “can I use [OP]’s song in my television commercial without risking a lawsuit?”.
Can you use a Beatles recording as a filler track for an album? No? Then why do you think someone’s photograph doesn’t deserve the same respect and protection?
Off course you can if you have the permission of the copyright holder and/or have purchased the right to use it in that way. If not then stand by for a heck of a lot of grief and expense.
That’s breach of copyright so the answer is no, unless you have asked his permission or that of his agency who might grant it for nothing.
In a word, No. Emil put it nicely; you will get sued for copyright infringement and probably a host of other things.
No. He owns the picture and its use. If you make any kind of products would it be ok for people to steal them?
